concepts.title: Parameters of Motion as Vectors or Scalars

summary.text: Motion parameters are classified as scalars (distance, speed, time) with magnitude only, or vectors (displacement, velocity, acceleration) with magnitude and direction.

importance.text: Foundation for all motion analysis. Direction matters—moving 5.0 m east then 5.0 m west gives 10 m distance but 0.0 m displacement.

explanations.text: Motion occurs in space. Position changes require direction specification—'5.0 meters' means nothing without 'which way'.
Space is isotropic—no preferred direction. Physics must specify which way objects move, not just how much.
Relativity demands it. Motion is relative, so direction relative to observer frame is essential information.

questions.text: Which quantity is a vector?

options.explanation: Speed is scalar—magnitude only, no direction specified.
Distance is scalar—path length without direction.
Correct. Velocity has both magnitude (30 m/s) and direction (north).
Time is scalar—duration has no directional component.

feedback.correct: Velocity requires both magnitude and direction.
feedback.incorrect: Vectors need both magnitude AND direction.
feedback.explanation: Only velocity includes direction. Speed, distance, and time are magnitudes only.

questions.text: A cyclist travels 8.0 km east, then 6.0 km west. Find distance and displacement magnitude.

options.explanation: Backwards. Distance is total path length, displacement is net change in position.
Correct. Distance = 8.0 + 6.0 = 14 km. Displacement = 8.0 - 6.0 = 2.0 km east.
Displacement considers direction. Net displacement is 2.0 km east, not 14 km.
Distance is total path traveled regardless of direction: 8.0 + 6.0 = 14 km.

feedback.correct: You correctly distinguished path length from net displacement.
feedback.incorrect: Distance = total path, displacement = net change in position vector.
feedback.explanation: Distance adds all path segments: 14 km. Displacement: 8.0 km east - 6.0 km west = 2.0 km east.

questions.text: A velocity of 50 m/s at 37° north of east has components:

options.explanation: Incorrect trigonometry. Use cos for adjacent (x) and sin for opposite (y) sides.
This would be purely eastward motion. The 37° angle creates both x and y components.
This would be purely northward motion. The angle from east axis creates an x-component.

feedback.correct: You applied trigonometry correctly to find vector components.
feedback.incorrect: Use vₓ = v cos θ and vᵧ = v sin θ where θ is measured from positive x-axis.
feedback.explanation: East: 50cos(37°) = 40 m/s. North: 50sin(37°) = 30 m/s. Remember: cos37° = 0.80, sin37° = 0.60.

questions.text: A car travels 120 km north then 160 km south in 4.0 hours. Average speed and velocity magnitude are:

options.explanation: Correct. Speed = total distance/time = 280/4.0 = 70 km/h. Velocity = displacement/time = 40/4.0 = 10 km/h.
Reversed. Speed uses total path distance, velocity uses net displacement.
Velocity magnitude differs from speed when path includes direction changes.
Speed calculation error. Total distance = 120 + 160 = 280 km, not displacement.

feedback.correct: You correctly used total distance for speed, net displacement for velocity.
feedback.incorrect: Speed = total distance/time. Velocity = displacement magnitude/time.
feedback.explanation: Distance = 280 km → speed = 70 km/h. Net displacement = 40 km south → velocity = 10 km/h.

questions.text: Three displacements: 12 m east, 9.0 m north, 5.0 m west. Net displacement magnitude is:

options.explanation: Correct. Net east: 12 - 5.0 = 7.0 m. Net north: 9.0 m. Magnitude = √(7.0² + 9.0²) = √130 = 11 m.
This adds magnitudes arithmetically. Vector addition requires considering directions.
Calculation error. Use Pythagorean theorem: √(7.0² + 9.0²).
Incorrect vector component calculation. East component is 12 - 5.0 = 7.0 m, not 4.0 m.

feedback.correct: You correctly added vector components then found the magnitude.
feedback.incorrect: Add x-components and y-components separately, then use Pythagorean theorem.

questions.text: Which operation is valid for vectors but not scalars?

options.explanation: Both scalars and vectors can be added and subtracted.
Both scalars and vectors can be multiplied by numbers.
Correct. Only vectors can be resolved into components because only vectors have direction.
Scalars already have magnitude. This operation applies to both.

feedback.correct: Component resolution requires direction, which only vectors possess.
feedback.incorrect: Consider which operations require directional information.
feedback.explanation: Resolving into components (x, y, z) requires direction. Scalars have no direction to resolve.

questions.text: Position vectors are measured from:

options.explanation: Starting point gives displacement, not position. Position needs a fixed reference.
Correct. Position vectors extend from a fixed origin to the object's current location.
While Earth's center can be an origin, any chosen origin works for position vectors.
This would give zero vector always. Position vectors originate from a reference point.

feedback.correct: Position requires a reference origin from which to measure.
feedback.incorrect: Position vectors extend from a fixed origin to the object's location.
feedback.explanation: Origin can be chosen arbitrarily, but must remain fixed for meaningful position vectors.

questions.text: Plane velocity relative to air: 200 km/h east. Wind: 50 km/h north. Ground velocity magnitude:

options.explanation: This subtracts the velocities. Perpendicular vectors add using Pythagorean theorem.
Correct. Perpendicular vectors: v = √(200² + 50²) = √42500 = 206 km/h.
This adds magnitudes arithmetically. Vector addition requires considering directions.
Calculation error. Use v = √(200² + 50²) for perpendicular vectors.

feedback.correct: You correctly applied vector addition for perpendicular velocities.
feedback.incorrect: For perpendicular vectors, use Pythagorean theorem: |v| = √(vₓ² + vᵧ²).
feedback.explanation: East and north are perpendicular. Resultant = √(200² + 50²) = 206 km/h.

questions.text: The difference between instantaneous and average velocity is:

options.text: Instantaneous uses displacement, average uses distance
options.explanation: Both use displacement. The difference is time interval: instant vs finite.

options.text: Instantaneous at one moment, average over time interval
options.explanation: Correct. Instantaneous velocity at specific time, average velocity over finite time period.

options.text: Instantaneous is always larger than average
options.explanation: No fixed relationship. Instantaneous can be larger, smaller, or equal to average.
They differ in time consideration: single instant vs time interval.

feedback.correct: Time interval distinguishes instantaneous from average quantities.
feedback.incorrect: Consider the time aspect: single moment vs extended period.
feedback.explanation: Instantaneous: velocity at specific time. Average: total displacement over time interval.

questions.text: Changing coordinate system orientation affects:

options.explanation: Correct. Magnitude is coordinate-independent, but components depend on axis orientation.
Magnitude is invariant under coordinate rotation. Components change with axis orientation.
Magnitude remains constant under coordinate transformations.
Components definitely change when coordinate axes rotate or translate.

feedback.correct: Physical quantities like magnitude are coordinate-independent.
feedback.incorrect: Consider what remains constant when you rotate coordinate axes.
feedback.explanation: Vector magnitude is physical reality. Components are mathematical projections onto chosen axes.

concepts.title: Kinematic Equations for Constant Acceleration
concepts.equation: v = u + at, v² = u² + 2as, s = ½(u + v)t, s = ut + ½at², s = vt - ½at²

summary.text: Five kinematic equations describe motion under constant acceleration. Each equation relates different combinations of initial velocity (u), final velocity (v), acceleration (a), displacement (s), and time (t).

importance.text: These equations solve all constant acceleration problems. Choose the equation that connects known quantities to the unknown quantity.

explanations.text: Constant acceleration means velocity changes at a steady rate. This creates predictable mathematical relationships between motion parameters.
Integration and differentiation connect position, velocity, and acceleration. Constant acceleration allows analytical solutions.
Newton's second law with constant force produces constant acceleration, making these equations universally applicable.

questions.text: To find final velocity when given initial velocity, acceleration, and time, use:

options.explanation: Correct. This equation directly relates final velocity to initial velocity, acceleration, and time.
This equation requires displacement, which is not given in the problem.
This equation finds displacement, not final velocity.
This requires final velocity, which is what we want to find.

feedback.correct: This equation directly connects the given quantities to final velocity.
feedback.incorrect: Choose the equation that contains all given quantities plus the unknown.
feedback.explanation: Given u, a, t, need v: v = u + at is the direct path.

questions.text: A car accelerates from 15 m/s to 35 m/s in 8.0 s. Calculate the acceleration.

steps.text: Given: u = 15 m/s, v = 35 m/s, t = 8.0 s

questions.text: Object with initial velocity 12 m/s accelerates at 3.0 m/s² for 6.0 s. Find displacement.

steps.text: Given: u = 12 m/s, a = 3.0 m/s², t = 6.0 s

questions.text: Ball thrown upward at 20 m/s reaches maximum height when:

options.explanation: Calculation error. At maximum height, v = 0. Use v = u + at: 0 = 20 + (-9.8)t.
Too long. Maximum height occurs when upward velocity becomes zero.
This would be the total flight time for return to ground, not maximum height.

feedback.correct: At maximum height, vertical velocity equals zero.
feedback.incorrect: Use v = u + at with v = 0 at maximum height.
feedback.explanation: v = 0 at max height: 0 = 20 + (-9.8)t → t = 2.0 s.

questions.text: When time is unknown and not needed, which equation is most useful?

options.explanation: This equation requires time, which is unknown.
Correct. This equation eliminates time, relating velocity, acceleration, and displacement.
This equation requires time, which is not available.
This equation requires time for the calculation.

feedback.correct: This equation eliminates time from kinematic relationships.
feedback.incorrect: Look for the equation that doesn't contain time (t).
feedback.explanation: v² = u² + 2as connects velocities, acceleration, and displacement without time.

questions.text: Car traveling 25 m/s brakes with deceleration 6.5 m/s². Calculate stopping distance.

steps.text: Given: u = 25 m/s, v = 0.0 m/s (stops), a = -6.5 m/s²

questions.text: Object accelerates from rest at 2.5 m/s² for 4.0 s, then constant velocity for 6.0 s. Total displacement:

steps.text: Final velocity after acceleration: v = u + at = 0 + 2.5(4.0) = 10 m/s

questions.text: Ball thrown downward at 8.0 m/s from 45 m height. Find velocity when hitting ground.

steps.text: Given: u = 8.0 m/s (downward), s = 45 m, a = 9.8 m/s² (downward)

questions.text: Two cars 180 m apart accelerate toward each other from rest. Car A: 2.0 m/s², Car B: 1.5 m/s². When do they meet?

steps.text: Let cars meet after time t
Distance traveled by A: sₐ = ½(2.0)t² = 1.0t²
Distance traveled by B: sᵦ = ½(1.5)t² = 0.75t²

questions.text: Object position: x(t) = 3.0t² + 2.0t + 5.0 (meters, seconds). Average velocity from t = 1.0 s to t = 4.0 s:

steps.text: Find positions at t = 1.0 s and t = 4.0 s

summary.text: Motion graphs reveal relationships between position, velocity, and acceleration. Slopes and areas provide physical meaning: slope of position-time gives velocity, slope of velocity-time gives acceleration, area under velocity-time gives displacement.

importance.text: Graphs handle complex motion that equations cannot. Non-uniform acceleration requires graphical or calculus methods.

explanations.text: Graphs visualize rate of change. Steep slopes mean rapid change, horizontal lines mean no change.
Calculus: derivative gives slope, integral gives area. Graphs are geometric calculus.
Physics is about rates: velocity is rate of position change, acceleration is rate of velocity change.

questions.text: On a position-time graph, the slope represents:

options.explanation: Acceleration is the slope of velocity-time graph, not position-time.
Correct. Slope = rise/run = Δposition/Δtime = velocity.
Displacement is shown by the vertical position values, not the slope.
Distance relates to total path length, not the slope of position vs time.

feedback.correct: Slope equals change in position divided by change in time.
feedback.incorrect: Remember: slope = Δy/Δx. For position vs time, this gives velocity.
feedback.explanation: Slope = Δposition/Δtime = velocity by definition.

questions.text: Area under a velocity-time graph represents:

options.explanation: Acceleration is the slope of velocity-time graph, not the area underneath.
Area gives displacement. Distance would require considering direction changes.
Correct. Area = base × height = time × velocity = displacement.
Average velocity would be total area divided by time interval.

feedback.correct: Area under curve gives displacement via integration.
feedback.incorrect: Think: area = base × height = time × velocity = ?
feedback.explanation: Area = time × velocity = displacement. This is geometric integration.

questions.text: On an acceleration-time graph, the area under the curve gives:

options.explanation: Correct. Area = time × acceleration = change in velocity (Δv = aΔt).
Area gives change in velocity. Final velocity = initial + change.
Displacement comes from velocity-time graph area, not acceleration-time.
Average acceleration would be total area divided by time interval.

feedback.correct: Area under acceleration vs time gives velocity change.
feedback.incorrect: Use dimensional analysis: [acceleration] × [time] = [velocity change].
feedback.explanation: Area = acceleration × time = change in velocity from Newton's laws.

questions.text: Constant velocity motion appears as what shape on a position-time graph?

options.explanation: Horizontal line means no position change (zero velocity), not constant velocity.
Correct. Constant velocity means constant slope on position-time graph.
Parabolic curves indicate changing velocity (constant acceleration).
Vertical lines are physically impossible (infinite velocity).

feedback.correct: Constant velocity means constant slope on position vs time.
feedback.incorrect: Constant velocity means position changes at steady rate.
feedback.explanation: Steady rate of position change creates straight diagonal line.

questions.text: A curved velocity-time graph always indicates non-uniform acceleration.

modelAnswer.text: True. Curved lines on velocity-time graphs indicate changing slopes, which means changing acceleration. Uniform (constant) acceleration produces straight lines on v-t graphs. Any curvature indicates the acceleration itself is changing over time, making it non-uniform.

feedback.correct: Curvature indicates changing acceleration.
feedback.incorrect: Consider what the slope of a velocity-time graph represents.
feedback.explanation: Curved v-t graph means changing slope, which means changing acceleration.

questions.text: Negative velocity on a velocity-time graph indicates:

options.explanation: Negative velocity indicates direction, not whether speed is increasing or decreasing.
Acceleration depends on the slope of the v-t graph, not the sign of velocity.
Correct. Negative velocity means movement opposite to the chosen positive direction.
Zero velocity means stopped. Negative velocity means moving in negative direction.

feedback.correct: Velocity sign indicates direction relative to chosen coordinate system.
feedback.incorrect: Velocity sign shows direction, not speed changes.
feedback.explanation: Positive/negative velocity indicates direction relative to chosen positive axis.

questions.text: When an object changes direction, the velocity-time graph:

options.explanation: Vertical lines represent infinite acceleration, which is non-physical.
Correct. Direction change means velocity goes from positive to negative (or vice versa), crossing v = 0.
Horizontal line means constant velocity, not direction change.
Velocity is continuous in physical motion. No sudden jumps occur.

feedback.correct: Direction change requires passing through zero velocity.
feedback.incorrect: Think about what happens to velocity when direction reverses.
feedback.explanation: To change direction, object must stop (v = 0) then move opposite way.

questions.text: Velocity-time graph shows constant 15 m/s for 4.0 s, then linearly decreases to 5.0 m/s over next 6.0 s. Find total displacement.

steps.text: Calculate area under velocity-time graph in two parts
Part 1 (0 to 4.0 s): Rectangle area = base × height = 4.0 × 15 = 60 m
Part 2 (4.0 to 10 s): Trapezoid area = ½(sum of parallel sides) × height

questions.text: Velocity changes from 20 m/s to 8.0 m/s over 3.0 s on a v-t graph. Calculate the acceleration.
If position increases at an increasing rate, the velocity-time graph must be a straight line with positive slope.

modelAnswer.text: False. If position increases at an increasing rate, velocity is increasing (positive acceleration). This means the velocity-time graph has positive slope, but it could be straight (constant acceleration) or curved upward (increasing acceleration). The statement is too restrictive—curved v-t graphs with positive slope also satisfy the condition.

feedback.correct: Position increasing at increasing rate allows various acceleration patterns.
feedback.incorrect: Consider whether curved v-t graphs can also show increasing position rate.
feedback.explanation: Increasing position rate means positive acceleration, but acceleration itself could be constant or changing.

summary.text: Momentum p = mv is the quantity of motion. More massive objects and faster objects have more momentum. Momentum is conserved in isolated systems.

importance.text: Momentum conservation explains collisions, explosions, and recoil. It is more fundamental than Newton's laws—momentum is conserved even when forces are unknown.

explanations.text: Mass and velocity together determine how hard it is to stop moving objects. A truck at 10 m/s has more momentum than a bicycle at 10 m/s.
Momentum relates to Newton's laws: F = dp/dt. Force causes momentum change, not motion itself.
Noether's theorem: spatial translation symmetry requires momentum conservation. This is deeper than Newton's laws.

questions.text: A 1200 kg car travels at 15 m/s. Its momentum is:

options.explanation: This divides mass by velocity. Momentum multiplies: p = mv.
This adds mass and velocity. Momentum multiplies them.
Correct. p = mv = 1200 × 15 = 18000 kg⋅m/s.
Right magnitude, wrong units. Momentum uses kg⋅m/s, not N.

feedback.correct: Momentum equals mass times velocity.
feedback.incorrect: Use p = mv to calculate momentum.

questions.text: Momentum is a vector quantity because:

options.explanation: Mass is a scalar quantity—it has magnitude but no direction.
Correct. Since p = mv and velocity is a vector, momentum inherits the directional property.
Magnitude size doesn't determine vector nature. Direction is the key factor.
Motion alone doesn't make something a vector. Distance involves motion but is scalar.

feedback.correct: Vector times scalar equals vector.
feedback.incorrect: Consider which quantities in p = mv have direction.
feedback.explanation: p = mv: mass (scalar) × velocity (vector) = momentum (vector).

questions.text: A 2.0 kg object moving at 6.0 m/s collides with a 3.0 kg object at rest. After collision, they stick together. Find their velocity.

steps.text: Apply conservation of momentum: p_initial = p_final
Initial momentum: p_i = m₁v₁ + m₂v₂ = 2.0(6.0) + 3.0(0) = 12 kg⋅m/s

questions.text: Two objects have equal momentum. Object A has mass m, Object B has mass 4m. Their kinetic energy ratio KE_A:KE_B is:

options.explanation: Equal momentum doesn't mean equal kinetic energy. KE depends on both momentum and mass.
Incorrect ratio. Use KE = p²/(2m) to compare energies at equal momentum.
Correct. KE = p²/(2m). For equal p: KE_A/KE_B = (2×4m)/(2×m) = 4.
Wrong calculation. Use KE = p²/(2m) for equal momentum comparison.

feedback.correct: Lighter objects have more kinetic energy at equal momentum.
feedback.incorrect: Use KE = p²/(2m) to compare objects with equal momentum.
feedback.explanation: At equal p: KE ∝ 1/m. So KE_A:KE_B = m_B:m_A = 4m:m = 4:1.

questions.text: A 0.50 kg ball changes velocity from 12 m/s east to 8.0 m/s west. The momentum change is:

options.explanation: This only considers the difference in speeds. Direction change means larger momentum change.
This only considers final momentum. Change = final - initial momentum.
Calculation error. Use Δp = m(v_f - v_i) with proper signs for direction.

feedback.correct: You correctly handled the direction reversal in momentum change.
feedback.incorrect: Remember: Δp = p_final - p_initial with proper vector directions.
feedback.explanation: Taking east as positive: Δp = 0.50(-8.0 - 12) = -10 kg⋅m/s (west).

questions.text: A 6.0 kg object at rest explodes into two pieces: 2.0 kg piece moves at 15 m/s north. Find velocity of the other piece.

steps.text: Mass of second piece: m₂ = 6.0 - 2.0 = 4.0 kg

questions.text: The SI unit for momentum is:

options.explanation: Correct. Momentum = mass × velocity, so units are kg × (m/s) = kg⋅m/s.
This is the unit for impulse, which equals momentum change, not momentum itself.
This is the unit for force (Newtons), not momentum.
This has wrong dimensions. Check: momentum = mass × velocity.

feedback.correct: Momentum units come directly from p = mv.
feedback.incorrect: Use dimensional analysis: [mass] × [velocity] = ?
feedback.explanation: p = mv: kg × (m/s) = kg⋅m/s.

questions.text: Observer A sees two 1.0 kg objects approach each other at 5.0 m/s each. Observer B moves with one object. Total momentum observed by B is:

options.explanation: This is correct for observer A, not B. Observer B sees different velocities.
This considers only one object. Observer B sees both objects with specific velocities.
Correct. Observer B sees one object at rest (0 m/s) and other at 10 m/s, giving total momentum = 1.0 × 10 = 10 kg⋅m/s.
Calculation error. Observer B sees velocities 0 and 10 m/s, not 5.0 and 10 m/s.

feedback.correct: Momentum depends on reference frame—different observers measure different values.
feedback.incorrect: Transform velocities to observer B's reference frame first.
feedback.explanation: Observer B sees: object 1 at 0 m/s, object 2 at 10 m/s. Total p = 0 + 10 = 10 kg⋅m/s.

questions.text: Three objects on a line: A (3.0 kg, 8.0 m/s east), B (2.0 kg, at rest), C (1.0 kg, 6.0 m/s west). If all collide simultaneously and stick together, find final velocity.

steps.text: Apply conservation of momentum (taking east as positive)

equations: p_i = m_A v_A + m_B v_B + m_C v_C

questions.text: In all collisions, both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved.

modelAnswer.text: False. Momentum is always conserved in collisions (assuming no external forces), but kinetic energy is only conserved in elastic collisions. In inelastic collisions, some kinetic energy is converted to other forms like heat, sound, or deformation energy. Perfectly inelastic collisions (where objects stick together) have maximum kinetic energy loss while still conserving momentum.

feedback.correct: Momentum conservation is universal, kinetic energy conservation is not.
feedback.incorrect: Consider what happens to kinetic energy in car crashes or clay collisions.
feedback.explanation: Momentum always conserved. Kinetic energy conserved only in elastic collisions.
